lines.text: Daddy?
Sara...

Daddy! Oh, Daddy! It is you! I found you! I found you! They said you were dead, but I knew you weren't! I knew you'd come back! Oh, Daddy, hold me, hold me close. You won't ever go away again, will you? Will you, Daddy? What's the matter, Daddy? Why don't you talk to me?
Sara...
Don't you know me, Daddy? I'm Sara! I'm Sara!
Sara... Where is my daughter...
Oh, Daddy! Something's happened to you! Mr. Bertie! Mr. Bertie! Oh, Daddy, you've got to know me! Look at me! Look at me! Oh, Daddy...
[sobs]
You musn't cry. You musn't cry. We must be good soldiers, you know.
But, I have been a good soldier, Daddy! And you don't know me!
My little Sara never cries...
But, I'm Sara! I'm Sara!
Sara... Sara! My little... My darling...
Oh, Daddy! You know me! You know me!
Sara, my darling! My baby Sara! Sara! Poor Sara, darling!
I thought you said you didn't have any more rooms.
I didn't know then what a dear little girl was coming.
lines.character: Amanda Minchin of Minchin Seminary for Girls

lines.text: Why does that make more rooms, Daddy?
Doctor this man is unknown. His papers were lost. Delirium following malarial fever.
Sara, I shall expect an explanation of this.
lines.character: Amanda Minchin of Minchin Seminary for Girls

lines.text: Yes, Miss Minchin. As soon as I can think of one.
Sara has no mother, and we've never been separated for more than a few days.
How touching.
lines.character: Amanda Minchin of Minchin Seminary for Girls

lines.text: This is going to be very hard on her.
Have no fear, Captain Crewe. I'm a mother to all my little girls.
lines.character: Amanda Minchin of Minchin Seminary for Girls

lines.text: Let's pretend we're back in India, and I'm going away with the troops for a few days. We've fought this kind of battle before, haven't we? And you never cried once when I went away, remember?
Yes, Daddy.
Well, this is going to be our hardest battle. We'll be good soldiers, won't we?
Yes, Daddy.
Shall we say goodbye like we used to at home?
Yes, Daddy.
Don't be frightened, Sara. It's only my grandfather.
Don't you believe him, young woman! I disowned him the day he was born!
And we're really very fond of each other.
Of course we are - what? Wait till I see the woman who runs this school! I'll put a spoke in your wheel!
Do! She'd love to know my grandfather is Lord Wickham, and she'll probably raise my salary!
Insolent pup! Just like his father!
Captain Crewe is dead. He was so reported in the list this morning. Moreover, he died bankrupt. His property and his mines were confiscated by the enemy.
You mean to tell me that the child is penniless, and she's left on my hands with nothing?
lines.character: Amanda Minchin of Minchin Seminary for Girls

lines.text: She's certainly left penniless, and she's certainly left on your hands. She hasn't a relative in the world that we know of.
I'll throw her out on the streets.
lines.character: Amanda Minchin of Minchin Seminary for Girls

lines.text: Do you think that wise, Miss Minchin? The reputation of your school, you know. That may not sound well to the parents of some of your other pupils. The child could be made to serve as your employee until her indebtedness is paid off.
Today, my good woman, the British army is behind me.
Hubert, that uniform! You're not going to war?
lines.character: Amanda Minchin of Minchin Seminary for Girls

lines.text: Quite. To the very cannon's mouth, if need be!
But why?
lines.character: Amanda Minchin of Minchin Seminary for Girls

lines.text: Because, old girl, I'm fed to the teeth with your bullying. And your treatment of Rose and little Sara is the last straw! I prefer the less painful horrors of the battlefield.
Are you daring to criticize me?
lines.character: Amanda Minchin of Minchin Seminary for Girls

lines.text: Astonishing, isn't it? But it proves that I'm competent to lead my men into the very jaws of death!
Please sir, were you with the troops at Mafeking?
Yes, of course I was. That's where I ran away, you know.
Did you know my father, Captain Crewe?

[cutting out a paper soldier]
Yes, yes of course. That's a fine-looking officer, isn't he? He ought to do well.
But where did you see my father last? Where is he now?
Where is who?
My father!

Of course one soldier more or less doesn't make any difference, you know. That's why I'm making thousands and thousands of troops for England. See? Good strong fellows who won't be afraid as I was. I was afraid. That's why I ran away, you know.
Mr. Bertie, he says he knows my father, but he won't tell.
He's living in a dream, Sara. He doesn't know what he's saying.
Here she is, on the bookshelves.
Bookshelves.
lines.character: Ram Dass, Lord Wickham's Indian Servant

lines.text: Oh... I pretend they're bookshelves filled with beautiful sets of books.
Then I'd better remove her before she ruins your set of Dickens. This is your room, Miss?
lines.character: Ram Dass, Lord Wickham's Indian Servant

lines.text: Yes, it's so little and so high above everything that it's like a nest in a tree. I can lie on my soft sofa and look up at the sky through that little hole in the roof.
Sofa?
lines.character: Ram Dass, Lord Wickham's Indian Servant

lines.text: Well... it looks more like a sofa when it's made up, and I imagine it has warm blankets and lovely cushions to curl up on.
But there is a fire at night, of course?
lines.character: Ram Dass, Lord Wickham's Indian Servant

lines.text: Well... that is the hardest of all to imagine, especially at night, but it's lovely when I can.
The cook wants you, and she's in an awful mood!
Excuse me, Ram Dass, I've got to go to the butcher's, and I'll get my ears boxed if I don't hurry!
You clumsy ox! For that, you'll whistle for your supper!
Oh, but, Mum, Sara never got no lunch. Everything's away before she got back from the butcher's.
Who do you think you're talking to? For that, you'll both go hungry! Now, clean up this mess!
Sara, where have you been? You've been out, haven't you?
lines.character: Amanda Minchin of Minchin Seminary for Girls

lines.text: Yes, Miss Minchin.
What do you mean by disobeying my orders?
lines.character: Amanda Minchin of Minchin Seminary for Girls

lines.text: I had to. I had to look for my father.
This ridiculous search for your father! All this making believe and refusing to face facts, it's indecent. I've had enough of it. You must realize once and for all that your father is dead.
lines.character: Amanda Minchin of Minchin Seminary for Girls

lines.text: Don't you say that! He's not dead, he's not! And you can't stop me from looking for him, either.
Do you see what I do?
I don't know what you see, but I don't think I believe what I'm seeing.
Well I never.
Do you feel that?
Yes, Miss.
What do you see?
I see a fire, Miss.
And a table with food on it, and a rug and a lamp, and slippers.
I do indeed, Miss. How did it all get here? Did you pretend it into happening?
I don't know. I've never pretended as good as this before. Look at these.
What happened to this room?
lines.character: Amanda Minchin of Minchin Seminary for Girls

lines.text: That's what we would like to know. I woke up this morning, and here everything was, even to the food and the fire.
Where did you get these things?
lines.character: Amanda Minchin of Minchin Seminary for Girls

lines.text: I don't know. It must be because I dreamed such a beautiful dream last night that it came true.
These things are rare and costly. You stole them!
lines.character: Amanda Minchin of Minchin Seminary for Girls

lines.text: No, Miss Minchin, I didn't steal these things!
I'll give you one more chance to tell me the truth!
lines.character: Amanda Minchin of Minchin Seminary for Girls

lines.text: But I am telling you the truth! They just - came!
This is a matter for the police!
lines.character: Amanda Minchin of Minchin Seminary for Girls

lines.text: What is it, child?

My father, they said he died at Mafeking. But I don't believe it! He may be here with the new wounded men, but they won't let me look! If they don't, I may never have another chance. Can you make them let me look?
Colonel, will you please see that this child is escorted through the wards?
With permission, I shall accompany her personally, Your Majesty.
What... what's your name?
Victoria. What's yours?
Sara... oh Your Majesty!
[kneels and kisses the Queen's hand]
You learning me by heart little Sara?
No daddy, I know you by heart. You're inside my heart.
Mr. Bertie, will it be all right if I come again tomorrow?
I shouldn't run away too often, princess. You might get punished, you know. I'll keep a sharp look out whenever the wounded come in.
You don't really believe he'll ever come, do you?
Yes, yes, of course I do. I told you missing men often turn up.
Then I'd better come. You might not know if he's very much changed.
All right, dear. You come.
Goodbye Mr. Bertie.
Goodbye dear.
[last lines]
Your Majesty. My Dad.
[Sara comes in Lavinia's room to clean out the fireplace where]
I hear you're being punished.

[to Jessie]
Do you think we ought to offer her a chocolate?
You might let her smell them.
Miss Minchin surely couldn't object to that. Would you care to?
I don't want to smell them and I don't want to eat them, thank you.
You don't? Why not?
I've had much nicer things than chocolate this morning.

[giggles at this]
Listen to the princess, pretending again.
I'm not pretending. I had the most wonderful things to eat that anyone ever had.

[frowns]
Why you little liar! You haven't even had breakfast!
Pardon me, but I really have; and if you'll excuse me for saying so, it isn't polite to call people liars.
How dare you talk back to me!

[sarcastically]
Tsk, tsk, tsk. Was I doing that? My goodness!
[Sara dumps ashes all over Lavinia and Jessie as they scream]

[runs off laughing]
So sorry!

[shouts and sobs]
YOU WAIT TILL I TELL MISS MINCHIN ON YOU!
Missy Sahib speaks Hindustani?
lines.character: Ram Dass, Lord Wickham's Indian Servant

lines.text: I've lived in India all my life.
Missy Sahib is going to live in England now?
lines.character: Ram Dass, Lord Wickham's Indian Servant

lines.text: Only until my father gets through making those Boers behave.
Missy Sahib has been a soldier?
lines.character: Ram Dass, Lord Wickham's Indian Servant

lines.text: Yes, my father's a captain. Captain Crewe.
Rose, something's wrong. What is it?
Miss Minchin has taken away my Thursday afternoons.
But why?
We mustn't be seen together.
Does that mean that I can never see you alone again?
Of course not, darling. No matter what Miss Minchin says, we'll find a way.
I can't understand the woman! What is she so afraid of? Why shouldn't we see each other?
Gossip, I suppose. Miss Minchin lives for that school and her ideas of pride and snobbishness.
Fiddlesticks! She's afraid of losing an excellent teacher whom she gets for nothing! I won't stand for it! I'll have a talk with her myself!
Oh no, darling, you mustn't do that. She'd only discharge us both.
She might not have the chance if things continue to pop in South Africa.
It's getting harder every day to pretend my father is safe.
I'll let you in on a little secret. I enlisted today, but while I don't want Miss Rose to know quite yet, I'll be going over there shortly.
To Mafeking? Then perhaps you can help my father.
We'll get him out.
Bertie, what do you think has happened? The princess found her father!
She found him!
Captain Crewe is alive?
lines.character: Amanda Minchin of Minchin Seminary for Girls

lines.text: Of course he's alive! How could she have found him if he wasn't alive?
Oh, Mr. Bertie, I've found my father!
Darling, I'm so glad!
[first lines]
Why are they sending so many soldiers, daddy, if it's only going to be a little war?
To make those stubborn Boers take us seriously this time, my darling. When they realize Her Majesty intends to put a stop to their nonsense, they'll quiet down.
They'd better. Anyhow, when you get there, you'll stop them. Won't you, daddy?
I'll do my best, dear.
[repeated line]
Sara, Sara.
